title: Help Make This Skill Better
date: Reviewed in the United States on February 19, 2017
content: Full disclosure, I am the developer of this skill.  I don't like self reviewing but Amazon does not provide a way to respond to reviews.  I'm sure they're working on a better review system but until then I feel I have to go this route.I've been able to contact a couple of the current reviewers and help them with their issues.  If you have a problem with this skill please contact me for assistance, I'm happy to help.  You can do this by emailing help@souschef.recipes or by using the Sous Chef Recipes companion app, click on the accounts tab, click on the ‚Äúi‚Äù information icon and then click contact us.If you install the Sous Chef Recipes app on you phone you'll find that we've added a how to section with videos that walk you through how to use the app and how to connect to this skill.  We're working on more videos about how to interact with this skill so look for those in the near future.Now I'll justify my biased five star review.  Many skills so far are novel or entertaining however I think this skill is actually useful.  I use it almost daily.  I built it for myself and I could have kept it that way but I found it so handy that I felt I had to share.  None of the reviews actually speaks to working with the skill.  It's not perfect by any means but I'd hate to go back to cooking without it.I think that Amazon and developers are both trying to figure out this nascent technology.  Right now we're in the growing pains stage.  If you, as a cutting edge technology user help us learn along the way, the better the future will be for everyone.  In five years we'll all wonder how we ever got along without our digital assistants.

title: Fantastic App for Show Echos
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 21, 2020
content: This app does what we really wanted, to have OUR recipes easily accessible in the kitchen. Voice controlled and easy to import. You can use a website, photo or text to import, which really gives us the flexibility to bring all of our recipes in one place. We use MS OneNote to store them, but showing them in the kitchen is problematic, so this is the bridge. I'll happily spend $0.99/year for this privilege. Why 4 stars? We would like the ability to organize into categories (Chicken, Grill, Desserts, etc) and the ability to alphabetize seems linked to the time of import. I can't seem to figure out how a few remain un-alphabetized. Also a web interface would VASTLY improve importing as it can be difficult on a mobile device.

title: Needs a lot of work to be an Alexa skill
date: Reviewed in the United States on February 17, 2020
content: I recently tested this out to see if it could replace mypepperplate for me now that mypepperplate is going to a paid platform and it doesn't have Alexa capabilities. Well, I just tried to use it on my Echo Show and it's awful. When I open the skill, it automatically opens to the last recipe. There is no way to view all recipes on the show and select on. And I tried using voice commands to open my recipe. Alexa wanted to know the exact name, I tried several shortened versions of the same recipe and it would only pull it up if I named the entire recipe. I have hundreds of recipes that I could put in, but I don't want to try to remember them all. It would be easier if I could just scan through my recipe list and adding a picture to my recipe would be nice.As others have complained, you have the ability to see either the ingredients list or the steps, not both side by side. So I am constantly flipping between the two... step 1, add tumeric, go to ingredients to see how much tumeric, back to steps, back to list..... ugh. I can use my voice and ask how much tumeric, and Alexa will answer, but she also opens the screen for that single ingredient and I have to ask her to go back to the steps, to which she starts reciting them again and I have to stop that and then look for the next step.As others have said, you have to type a recipe in, one ingredient at a time and one step at a time. 10 years ago, pepperplate had the ability to just import a recipe from a website or let you copy and paste entire paragraphs and it would sort it out for you. I could copy an entire list of ingredients from a word doc and then paste it in pepperplate and it would sort the ingredients up as individual ingredients for me (there were some glitches and I had to check to make sure they were all there, but 95% of the time it worked). Same with steps, I could copy all steps and it would separate them for me. 10 years later, I expect this as a standard with any future apps or sites.I am disabling this skill for now and wouldn't recommend it. I might try it again in 5 years.

title: As Far As Apps Go, I Usually Think They're Pointless And Going Nowhere Fast.... But THIS Is A GEM of a Beginning!
date: Reviewed in the United States on April 4, 2018
content: Those Beginning Ideas That Are Already Great Or Only Need Minimal Tweaking In The Future: 1) I can enter my recipes, I can share recipes with other people I know using this app, and I can link to recipe websites through the app. 2) I appreciate the time-savers... to add things from my menu item recipe's ingredient list to my shopping list as I peruse them, and being able to scale recipes up or down! 3) The recipe input methods initially bothered me and took some adjustments.  The camera to simply take pictures, isn't as easy as you would think, but it IS still in beta testing.  I WISH it could have a way to input the recipes on the computer, on a nice big screen you can see, and a keypad that isn't blocking the view of where and what you're typing.  I just bought a blue-tooth keyboard for my phone as a compromise. Hand typing entire recipes into my phone under those conditions was a deal-breaker, so I found a way to live with it.  What I hope to see in the near future: 1) I'd like to add pictures of my creations to the recipes I input, saves a lot of description space and keeps the end presentation of foods right (can't have a plate full of mushy looking white foods, for example). 2) I'd like Echo Show to be able to show me what I see on screen in the app... ingredients list, steps list, notes, etc.  Alexa shows me nothing... meaning I can't use her... I have to use my phone app, which defeats MY purpose in the kitchen. I refuse to touch anything but the foods when I cook, so this is possibly going to be a deal breaker. 3) I'd like to be able to link recipes together for planned meals as well.  For example:  I make some meals that everything served for that meal is ALWAYS the same because it is perfection when put together.  I would like to tie entire menus together, if at all possible.  I'm just a farm wife that cooks for a lot of hired hands and/or other large groups, but this app shows some true potential for an app I would pay well for, and I bet other farm/ranch wives and/or caterers would as well!

title: Best we‚Äôve got but needs a lot of work for Echo show
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 1, 2020
content: I was looking for a skill that would let me pull up my own written recipes or recipes I find on random websites up on my echo show and this seems to be the only skill to do this. Unfortunately, the skill on thr Show forces you use voice commands to pull up recipes rather than having an option to click them. It often mishears what you say. Also once you get a recipe up it puts echo into a mode to receive a new command, so unless you click off or are very silent it interpreta anything you utter as a command to give you step by step instructions on the recipe. Never have I wanted to see only one line of a recipe. Also, once it goes into this mode theres no back command or button to get back to the full recipe so you have to ask for the recipe again. All voice command which is horrible. Makes for a very frustrating experience. But again its all we have. Please stop making everything go through voice and allow for touch commands as well.

title: I love this skill!
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 8, 2018
content: I've been meaning to try out this skill since getting my Echo and I finally did tonight. Sometimes Alexa doesn't correctly hear me so I have to repeat myself. The list of ingredients and steps is read out quickly so I found myself needing to tell Alexa to stop after a few, get the ingredients, and then ask her to say the ingredients again to hear the rest (The ingredients are listed from the beginning every time). Other than those things, I really enjoyed cooking while asking Alexa what to do next.Inputting recipes felt simple and easy enough for me. I like that you can highlight the portion of text on a webpage that is the name, ingredients, and steps. No need to manually write everything down, or even copy and paste!Did you know you can meal plan with the app too? I just found that out. Can you set up recipes in advance and then ask what is for dinner today? Or something like that? That would be a nice addition.

title: Only App I've Found For Personal Recipes. Definitely Recommend!
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 1, 2020
content: Just started using this app and so far I'm impressed.  I haven't been able to find any other recipe app that will work with my recipes and echo show.  I've read a couple of other reviews stating you can't see all the recipes or Ingredients side-by-side with steps.  I have attached photos show that it is possible.  Could be that the developer added this feature after that review.  I am using the app on a Fire tablet 10 under the 'show' mode.  This could also explain the difference.This app is definitely a work-in-progress so no 5-star.  I would recommend going to website and view the help videos.  This explained how to use the app.Pros:Can use my own recipes and have echo show display them hands-free.Only app I could find that would work this way.Can import from website, text or camera.Cons:Importing from website is only on iphone app. (edit:works on fire tablet but not their website.)You need to cleanup the text or the program will not recognize the incredients (e.g. no bullets before ingredients).Not very intuitive.Create account on phone app or website before linking Alexa skill.Great app so far and thumbs up to developer.  Keep up the good work.

Plus, as i mentioned above, having separate sections for the ingredients and steps would break it up better.But again, just happy to have something over nothing.  Text size is good!

title: These Reviews Are For The Alexa Skill!
date: Reviewed in the United States on March 29, 2020
content: Not sure what these negative reviews are all about being that the intent is to review the skill here.  To begin, the skill is great and works exactly as designed...and it is dynamic to wht you are cooking! Ask the temperature and it tells you the internal and external temps...in either Celsius or Fahrenheit, depending on whst you chose in the MEATER app. This skill works perfectly and I have asked it multiple questions with 100% accuracy.  #1 Rule...read the instructions before using something new!Second, since others have decided to trash the product unfairly her for some reason, let me dispell some falsehoods seen in other ‚Äúreviews‚Äù and help those that are new to the MEATER product.- One, remove the plastic piece from the battery compartment on the bottom of the block/case the probe is in.  This will allow the battery to charge the probe.- Two, you MUST let the probe charge for at least four hours like the instructions tell you before pairing the probe to your smarphone or tablet.  There is a monitor in the probe that ensures the 4 hour inital charge is completed.  I promise, you wait and it will connect with no issue.- Three, make sure you set the temperature settings to Celsius or Fahrenheit.  That is how it will show message temps in Alexa.- Four, when you first successfully pair your probe you will then be given the opportunity to create your new account.  After this is successful and you are complete in the setup process within the app, then and only then can you enable the Alexa skill.- Five, the online support wizard is excellent. This will intuitively walk you through to find the answer to your question.  If you still need help, simply select No at the bottom that it did not resolve your problem.  It will then take you to an contact us form to submit to support.  They will then contact you...and quickly!I have used many types of temp probes over the years and this by far is the best and most intuative ever. Love this product and you will too.  Just follow the instructions.

The music curation is also spot on ‚Äì it's such a fun and innovative way to approach the art of cooking. Definitely one of my favorite Alexa skill so far!

title: Good once you know the rules
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 30, 2021
content: Had to play around with the app and my Echo Show a bit to figure out why some recipes were not showing up. Make sure if you imported a recipe from another website that you change the Source to "Recipe Keeper" afterwards or it won't show up on the Echo Show.Also, asking Alexa for your recipes requires you to know the exact keyword (can be the Name, Course, Category, or Collection). For example, I have a German Gl√ºhwein recipe, which is tagged with Course: Beverage and Category: Alcoholic. When I ask Alexa to pull up it by name, she didn't understand, nor did she understand when I said "show me alcoholic beverages." Only when I said "show me alcoholic recipes" did she successfully pull up the recipe.So yeah it just takes a bit of getting used to. Could be improved to be more intuitive/intelligent, but maybe one day...

title: Pretty good so far
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 3, 2020
content: I'm giving 4 stars at the moment because it works for me! Losing one star at the moment because its not as smooth as it could be e.g. you have to exit the app between looking at recipes otherwise she doesn't recognize the next one.  I'm using my kindle fire tablet in 'show' mode.  I ask Alexa 'Ask recipe keeper for cheese recipes' and she says she has 17 recipes (from my recipe collection) and you see them listed, and can scroll thru.  Then either ask her for recipe by number (she doesnt recognise by name) or just pick it on screen.  If you want another recipe, you must exit (Alexa, exit) and give her about 30 seconds.  Then start again with 'Alexa ask recipe keeper for..)  So she is a bit clumsy at the moment, but its a good start.  Now ive got to figure out how to keep kindle from going to sleep lol.

title: needs work, and a command list
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 19, 2020
content: not very intuitive, still have to touch the screen to scroll to select a recipe. Unless you happen to know the exact recipe number. cannot differentiate between crock pot, slow cooker. does not understand titles. For example I have a recipe entitled french dip sandwiches. If I ask it to open french dip sandwiches recipe. It cannot do that. However if I say open slow cooker recipes then scroll to recipe 47 I can then select it. cannot start a timer from within the app. You must exit the app start the timer and then go back into the app and find the recipe again. what I ended up doing was renamed in my kitchen device Alexa, and my living room device computer so I can yell to the living room to start the timer while using the one in the kitchen.

title: Could be the best recipe app out there. Almost is!
date: Reviewed in the United States on February 28, 2022
content: Start off I didn‚Äôt hesitate to pay for the pro version here‚Äôs why.Looking to digitally store your own recipes for instant access while your shopping or simply wanting to make a shopping list from those recipes?Wanting a quick way to find your recipe, to follow while your cooking?Hands down the best app I‚Äôve tried to date. I‚Äôve tried many.Easy to automatically scan in a recipe from a recipe card, magazine etc. by using your phones camera.  You can  automatically upload from a recipe you found website .The app is Easy to navigate as well. I‚Äôm sure the developer spent a ton of time on this app.The 1 bad and definitely needs work thingEcho show integrationI wanted to find not just a great iPhone app but I wanted to use my echo show in my kitchen for recipes. Echo has a Nice big screen to follow while you cook. It just makes sense to keep it in your kitchen for cooking.It seems like it does kinda work but the developers didn‚Äôt quite finish the job.I have figured out how to finally see my recipes show up on the echo show. But it will take some playing around with.First offSynchronizing the phone app with a list of recipes that I had entered, to the echo show wasn‚Äôt that difficult.Especially when following the help guide located in the apps settings area.Once that‚Äôs done you will see some recipes on the Echo but maybe not your recipes. For instance the example recipes that came with the app. To fix this issue. You need to go into every one of your recipes u entered and the first page of the recipe file you need to change the source field to..‚Äùrecipe keeper‚Äù Leave out the quotation marks of course.A few minutes later you will see your recipes Show up. However they won‚Äôt just show up on the echo show Without perfectly asking the Echo show for the exact recipe that you were looking for. For instance ‚Äú Alexa ask recipe keeper  Brandie‚Äôs barbecue‚ÄùWhich can be difficult sometimes.  When you don‚Äôt remember the title of the recipe exactly.So I found a way to get the echo show to show all my recipes. With some trial and error I found that if you say this correctly, you will see all of your recipes show up.‚ÄúAlexa.  Ask recipe keeper.  Show all recipes ‚ÄúFrom there I can scroll through and pick the one I want to see.However there is one more issue I‚Äôm working through which I think I can eventually figure out.Out of my 30 some recipes I have added, it‚Äôs only showing 15 of them on the echo show. I have triple checked to make sure I properly entered ‚Äúrecipe keeper‚Äù in the source field.I‚Äôm kind of wondering now if the photo I used for that recipe may be too big in size.  I‚Äôll keep trying to troubleshoot this problem.Anyways great phone app for holding your recipes.I really hope the app developers improve upon the Echo show portion of this app.If they perfected it like they did the phone app. I can‚Äôt see why they couldn‚Äôt mass-market this and make it the most Widely used recipe app out there.

title: Works well, have to spend some time to learn it
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 21, 2018
content: Short version:  It takes a little work up front but does a great job of freeing up your hands.Long Version: This is exactly what I wanted in a cooking skill.  You go to the website, put the steps in, and then ask alexa for each step in order (you can go backward and forward).  When I cook my hands are messy and I tend to forget the order of things and how much.  This makes it really simple to find out what to do next without having to wash my hands and open my phone.A couple of things that will help you when you use it:1. Break each step into it's smallest possible unit "Add 1 cup flour", "add 1tsp salt", etc.  Then when you get them read back to you its one simple thing and you're not trying to parse a long instruction.2. Voice search on your recipes is possible and works fairly well: you don't need the code.3. After ten seconds or so it boots you out of the skill, instead of going back into it use the "ask" syntax: "Alexa ask youchef to repeat", "Alexa ask youchef next".  It's not natural but once you get a handle on it it's pretty easy, it makes timers easier to manage while you're cooking (you can't set them or check on them in the app).I don't use the ingredient feature much:  If you mention an ingredient in a step you can ask how much and it will tell you.  When I played around it seemed to work well but it was simpler for me to put the amount in each step.All in all a great tool in the kitchen and worth your small time investment.

title: Not good enough!
date: Reviewed in the United States on May 3, 2018
content: In spite of the constant use upon so many months & even far more than a year or more of the unit getting to know my speech patterns, this meal planner is a far cry from a decently functional state to even come close to meeting my needs, never mind my satisfaction which was instantly turned to dissatisfaction when I enabled the meal planner skill but it wasn't working the same as I had expected as with all the other skills I have enabled.It needs a great deal of work before it can be a usable skill that can also be viewed from my Alexa cell phone app so IF the unit screws up, I can correct it manually. This Meal planner should also be listed within the collective of lists when it is activated but it isn't which is very disappointing, considering that a meal plan, is actually a list within itself. Plus, it has to be able to store more than just a week of meal plans with the option to reschedule a plan when a disruptive event should occur to prevent the original meal plan from being fully implemented.

title: A million miles away from useful

Without 2) and 3) I just can't be bothered.Give me 4) and I will sing your praises to all who will listenWithout me 5) and 6) I'll keep using it but I'll grumble about the app

title: I think it could be great if it had more recipes but I understand that ...
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 10, 2017
content: Just started playing around with this and I will update review after using it more often.  I think it could be great if it had more recipes but I understand that it is still under construction and a lot of recipes are submitted by users so as it grows this will improve rapidly.  It is very easy to add your recipe and also to add recipes you want to try from websites.  I added a few keto and paleo friendly recipes to try it out.  You will have to spend a few minutes tweaking the ingredients from website but this isn't too difficult.  Also a lot of the recipes I added don't have nutritional info because a lot of the ingredients I use were not available in their database.  Two additions I think would make it outstanding would be to have a shopping list available from the ingredients list and I would like to be able to pause the recipe as I am preparing it so I can follow it step-by-step.  Otherwise it's just easier to go to the website and click the link to get the recipe.

title: I'd like a list of what I've stored in my freezer ...
date: Reviewed in the United States on February 12, 2017
content: The main flaw with the skill is it doesn't develop a written list that I can read on my mobile phone.  I want to have access to such a list when I'm at the grocery store to see what I have on hand so I purchase accordingly.  I'd like a list of what I've stored in my freezer that looks like the shopping list that can be developed with Echo. Listening in my kitchen -- which is where we keep our Echo -- to Alexa verbally run through all the stuff in my freezer would take an eternity.  And that's not where I most need the info. Afterall, there I can just open the freezer and look.  Again, I want access to the info at the grocery store.  Ideally, the list would sort alphabetically by food item and numerically by freezer date, so it's clear what I have and what's fresh and what's not.  I really hope that this issue gets resolved or that an innovator is inspired to develop a skill that includes this feature.  I'd pay for it.

title: Needs some human/machine interface work, but it functions
date: Reviewed in the United States on April 25, 2017
content: Unlike some of the other reviewers, I haven't had any issue at all removing items. In fact, that now seems to be the default setting. When adding an item, if the Echo got it wrong and I said no, it immediately assumed I wanted to delete something. On the plus side, asking it to delete something was really easy and it worked. On the negative side, if I said I wanted to add something, I'd be asked, "What do you want to add?" If I just said the name of the product, it would switch gears and ask me if I wanted to delete the item. ONLY by following up the question by prefacing my food item with the word "Add" again, would she keep out of the delete loop. I really only got this skill so that I wouldn't have to go open everything in the kitchen to figure out what I wanted to eat... I like the idea of Alexa just telling me what's in there so I can decide while I'm doing something else that doesn't involve pawing through an open fridge. This allllllmost gets me there. Not loving the 3 item repeat limit, especially for that purpose.Not loving the attitude this skill makes my Echo throw when I quit, either. "Fine - leave me..." What the crap, Glad? Don't hijack my Alexa's default "personality"... that's jarring and kind of rude. If I want my Echo to throw shade I'll go enable one of the insult skills. It's extra not cute when the skill set is still kind of spotty.

title: Almost great!
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 24, 2016
content: This skill would be perfect if:1) it dropped "glad" from the activation name2) it didn't ask you if you want to do anything more or make silly jokes at the end3) it didn't prompt you to confirm every time.It's a neat idea and very useful but the points above make interaction with it just slightly annoying.Instead of "Alexa, tell leftovers to add chicken to the fridge" "OK, added chicken to the fridge" you end up with "Alexa, tell glad leftovers to add chicken to the fridge".  "I think I heard add chicken to the fridge, is that right?" "Yes" "OK, added chicken to the fridge.  Do you want to add or remove anything else?" "No" "leaving me so soon, blah blah blah".Please update it!

title: Time is not the issue...
date: Reviewed in the United States on March 18, 2019
content: Temperature is. The degree of doneness is established by temperature in sous vide cooking; not so much time, at all. OK for eggs, yeah time is important but you will want a visual guide for them anyways till you learn what you like. Fish, well time is somewhat important but not to where an extra 15-20 minutes cooking will just ruin it. No, temperature in relation to desired doneness (well, medium, rare) is what sous vide cooking requires. 2-5 degrees can make the difference between just ok and delicious. This app delivers that info and does a fine job of it.

title: Life changing

title: No fumbling around with handheld devices, simply speak to eat.
date: Reviewed in the United States on February 20, 2018
content:
The media could not be loaded.
                




  ¬†The hubby and I love the idea of voice ordering but don‚Äôt have a Fazoli‚Äôs near us, so we were excited to try this out on a recent trip through Colorado. I‚Äôve posted a video below if you want to see how it went.With Alexa, I‚Äôve learned it‚Äôs best to keep things simple‚Äîuse common words, speak clearly, pause for her replies and be ready to try other phrases if she doesn‚Äôt understand right way. If you watch the video, you‚Äôll see that she did misinterpret one or two things, but it was easy to recover by choosing different words.We successfully placed an order, charged it to our card, picked up the food, ate and thoroughly enjoyed it, especially those garlic breadsticks‚Ä¶ Oh man! So good.I do think this is bleeding-edge technology, so you need a little patience.

title: Hands free food ordering? Yes!!!
date: Reviewed in the United States on February 21, 2018
content:
The media could not be loaded.
                




  ¬†Being able to order lunch without having to fumble with my phone is amazing! I wish more restaurants made it this easy!I like the fact that Alexa walks you through everything to place your order including confirming the pick up location. Alexa also walked me through the menu and it was very easy to check out. Since I have a cold, I had to make sure to talk clearly so Alexa could understand my commands.Great experience! I plan on telling my friends about it!

title: Good, but auto status updates would make it better!
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 4, 2022
content: I'm pretty sure almost all Dominos fans like the tracker in the phone app... and you can now ask Alexa for updates on your order, and she will notify you when it arrives! The one big thing it lacks is "live" status updates. I don't want to just know when the pizza's here -- the knock on my door tells me that. I'd like to hear that my order's being put in the oven, that it's on its way, that the driver is a few minutes away. The location near me sometimes gets INSANELY busy, and it'd be nice to have Alexa tell me when it's moving along rather than having to keep poking the app to see what's going on with my pizza.Setup and linking instructions were also a little unclear, which might make it needlessly difficult for some, but I was able to figure it out without too much hassle. Would be nice to see this process made a little simpler somehow.

title: Works but is less convenient than the app
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 3, 2020
content: Everything works but, honestly, the regular app on the phone is more convenient. To get the update of my order I have to ask Alexa to ask Dominos every time and then wait for her to ask me what phone number I used... then wait a little longer and finally the update..... but I already got the answer on my phone 2 seconds after I picked up my phone. It would be nice if Alexa could just speak the updates as they occur rather than my having to ask all the time and keep reciting the phonebook in a crowded room... Or at least give the update with needing the phone number every time.

title: It does notify you when it's there
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 23, 2020
content: Though it does notify you when it's there I was really hoping it would fo the live notifications like the Domino's tracker does. I expected to hear Alexa say "Your order is being prepared" "Your order is in the oven" etc.

title: Almost Perfect
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 29, 2019
content: I was very excited to use this app, until I got to the checkout and found that the price was more than DOUBLE the price of the app.  The app allows coupons, but Alexa doesn't, which turned a $20 deal into $42!!!.  I will not be using this at all.  If coupons were allowed, I would rate this 5 starts and use it all the time.  I order pizza from dominoes almost every night too.  Too bad, this is just one tiny step away from being the perfect Alexa app

title: Magic. The future is now.
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 29, 2016
content: Absolutely fantastic. I don't always order the same thing every time, but there is a certain order I consider my "favorite." I have that set as my Easy Order. When I'm home and the wife isn't, I just shout to the void, "Alexa, tell Dominos to place my Easy Order." Then, like magic, pizza arrives at my doorstep about 20-30min later. If, for some reason, pizza has not arrived within 20min or so... I once again shout into the void, "Alexa, ask Dominos where my pizza is." Then the void answers back, "It's out for delivery." Magic. Seriously, the future is now.In seriousness, I almost gave 4 stars instead of 5 because of that limitation. It can only repeat your last order, or place your Easy Order. I can't think of a viable solution for ordering something more complicated, though. By the time Alexa walked you through which coupons, pizza, crust, and toppings you want... it would probably have been easier just to grab your phone or laptop. Maybe. What do I know. I look forward to the time when I can find out for myself.

content: I was able to get this working in a few easy steps, download the Domino's app to my phone from the app store. Setup an account. Place my first order. title: Voice Activated Pizza Delivery System, or ALEXA for short.
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 11, 2016
content: It finally works. I have no idea why it started working, but I can now order pizza through Alexa. I didn't make any changes, just decided to try it again and it worked. It works rather well now, and you can even ask Alexa what is in the order incase you forget what it was, as well as ask where your order is...as the pizza guy can never find my house and so I have to wait outside for him. I would love to be able to set up multiple orders for different occasions. Just being able to ask for orders by a preset list created on their website would be nice. I rarely order the same thing twice in a row, so it would be nice to have some variety.(Original Post - 1star)Says I have an invalid payment method. No noticeable way to correct what works fine for paying when using any other way of buying Domino's Pizza. so until they fix it, this is a waste.(Update below-11-4-2016 - one star)I have attempted to use Alexa again to order Pizza. I redid the entire account on both Alexa and on Domino's. From there website with all the same info I can order without any issues, but from Alexa I still get a generic "invalid Payment Error". It doesn't explain what is wrong with my account, and calling customer service from Dominoes, they couldn't see anything wrong either.Now, payment issue aside, Alexa hears the commands without issue and attempts to order my pre-saved order that I set on Dominoes Website, but I guess I've got to get off the couch and login to the computer and order the pizza the not so old-fashion way. Will try again the next time I see an update for the app.

content: After going through all the motions as instructed, the app set up fine.  Used it and it confirmed the order was made and gave a 25-35 minute estimate. Did NOT ORDER THE FOOD.I dont mind if new tech has a glitch. The problem is, this app doesnt CONFIRM, but it TELLS YOU IT DID.  Alexa was very convincing telling me my order was complete and when it was coming; then she starved my family.Only orders pre saved "meals" and you arent getting specials. still would be useful if it worked, but I dont know why someone made the decision to falsely confirm an order. Dumb, because this actually hurts the brand.

title: Forget about the hassle!
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 12, 2019
content: Hello, my name is Guther with a J and in this review I will be explaining how Where the Truck is the app for you. In this app, you are instantly rewarded with a complementary 6 oz. ration food card. This card, when alerted, will send a full food truck right to your door! Mine was a pizza truck. Thank goodness, cause I wasn't gonna take sushi or some barbaric form of disrespect. Anyways, ration food cards cost a fortune. At least $319.99. A real arm and leg! Gladly though, I can replace those since I am a dentist. I work for Ron's Funhouse Denistry. I will be buying ration food cards for weeks and weeks.Thanks again,Guther with a J.

title: Inspiring app.
date: Reviewed in the United States on June 15, 2016
content: When I cook I like to check out some recipes to get some ideas. I usually don't have all the ingredients and most likely won't go to the store to buy a shallot when I already have an onion on hand. That being said, I checked out Chef Basil and searched for some basic recipes just to see what would turn up, (no turnip recipes though). Wait... On second thought, I just searched turnip, and it did offer me a few including a Turnip Fries recipe, which sounded yummy. The search almost always had 3 recipes for me to choose from. For example if you search meatloaf, it will say we found 3 recipes, meatloaf, meatloaf. & meatloaf. Umm, Alexa I'll try the meatloaf. Sometimes the recipe just has ingredients, and to be honest that's ok with me as I usually wing it anyhow. I just need to be inspired, and Chef Basil did inspire me! There are definitely some things that need to be worked out, and I wouldn't mind a reverse recipe look up feature where you give some ingredients that you have and Alexa says 'Dude, you can make a quiche!"  That would be cool.

title: Early stage prototype
date: Reviewed in the United States on June 6, 2016
content: Chef Basil represents an interesting concept, but it is definitely still a prototype in its early stages of development. For instance, when you open the app, you can search for a recipe, but when you open that recipe, sometimes there are no steps. It also experiences errors relatively frequently (Chef Basil is acting up right now, please try again in a little while).Most importantly, there doesn't seem to be a way for it to track where you were in the recipe once you exit (at least I haven't been able to figure it out). For recipes, which usually have multiple steps, this is a major problem.
